blocks.text: Let \( f'(a) = 0 \) when \( a = 130 \) and \( f''(a) = 132, so that f'(a) = 0 \) at \( a = 130 \) and \( f''(a) \) has a value 130.
Thus the expansion may be rewritten as:

blocks.description: This formula represents the Taylor series expansion of a function around a point a.

blocks.text: Exercises 11 â€” On the Calculation of Small Corrections and Expansion in Series.
1. If \( R_1 = \left( \frac{dR}{dh} \right) \) where \( R_1 \) is the resistance at elevation h.
2. The height of one point \( A \) of a station in a survey is measured, and let there be a possibility of an error of 1 in vertical elevation (if it is measured as 1 instead of 0).
3. If a tank of water has a height of 4 feet, the rate of flow is about \( 5 \times 6 \sqrt{\frac{g}{h}} \) where \( g \) is a constant.
4. In a certain room, the water is 3 feet high, and it is possible to measure to a solution of 0.2.
5. If the number of revolutions per minute is \( N \) and \( V = W + h \).

blocks.latex: W = W + \frac{P}{N} \cdot h, \text{ where } h = \frac{h}{200} \text{ or } h = 1 \text{ is the height due to a change in speed from 200 to 190}.
blocks.description: An equation representing the relationship between work, power, and height.
